abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic and Social
            Development Policy Loan/Credit Project for Grenada were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            a programmatic approach, which supports a multi-stage
            program with a longer term horizon, is superior to a
            stand-alone one year program. At the Regional Operations
            Committee meeting of this Development Policy Loan (DPL)/DPL
            held in December 2009, both peer reviewers of this operation
            as well as comments by other participants strongly supported
            a programmatic approach. Eventually, a stand-alone operation
            was favored because of the high uncertainty and debt risk of
            Grenada at that point in time. With hindsight, a
            programmatic operation could have had stronger development
            impact and, by presenting a schedule of possible future
            financial support. In small states, policy based programs
            need to be relatively simple and straightforward. Since
            generally only one policy based operation is prepared in a
            multi-year period, both the Government and the Bank tend to
            include many activities in the program. However,
            implementation capacity is usually not strong in these
            countries. Thus, in order to increase the likelihood that
            programs are fully implemented, it would be useful to design
            highly selective and relatively simple programs. In
            addition, following up with intensive technical assistance
            and country dialogue that builds local capacity would help
            during implementation and also enhance sustainability of the
            reform program in the medium term. The Program Policy Matrix
            needs to be concise, with few measures and outcome
            indicators that are clearly defined, critical for the
            performance of the Program, and that are within control of
            the government.
